newsitem.title: INDONESIA: Indonesia rupiah firms, swaps fall in late trading.
newsitem.headline: Indonesia rupiah firms, swaps fall in late trading.

text.p: The Indonesian rupiah firmed against the dollar in sleepy late trading on Tuesday but swaps trading was active, dealers said.

"It's a sleepy day. The rate has moved in a narrow range of 30 cents since the morning," one U.S. bank dealer said. "There is no fresh factor. Overall sentiment on the rupiah remains bullish," the dealer said.
Spot rupiah was quoted at 2,324.25/24.50 at 0845 GMT against an opening of 2,324.25/24.50.
Tomorrow and today rupiah closed at 2,323.80/23.90 and 2,323.00/23.25, respectively.
Dealers said, however, the relatively active swap market had helped provide some life.
One dealer said overnight money fell to 10.0/11.0 percent late in the afternoon from 16 percent at the opening.
He said short-dated swaps also declined on expectation of an easing in money market conditions following fresh inflows of civil servants' salaries transferred by the government.
He said state banks were seen unloading short-term swaps which might indicate the beginning of fresh transfers.
Overnight swap was at 0.65/0.70. Tom/next swap declined to 0.46/0.47 points from 0.57/0.60 points.
Another reason was the expectation of some fresh rupiah supply following central bank's dollar buying on Monday.
One state bank dealer said Bank Indonesia was estimated to have absorbed about $200 million from the market after the spot rate fell out of the band.
Dealers said the amount sold to the central bank was not significant because of a relative lack of trading activity.
The U.S. bank dealer said declines in short-term swaps had helped drag down longer-term swap premiums.
"Sentiment on longer-term swaps was bearish. Some players seemed to anticipate narrowing interest rate differentials between the two currencies," the dealer said.
He said they were expecting possible higher U.S. interest rates in the short-term while more downside was anticipated for the rupiah, narrowing the differential.
One-month swap was quoted at 17.3/17.75, two at 32.5/33.25, three at 49.50/50.25 and six at 98.0/98.75 points.
One foreign bank dealer said operators were uncertain over the short-term trend because they could not push the dollar further down due to the central bank floor rate for dollars.
However, there was no incentive to buy dollars, keeping the market hovering around the band in lethargic trade, he said.
He said a firm stand by the central bank to defend the band seemed to have discouraged further speculation for now.
The central bank kept its intervention rate unchanged at 2,324/2,516 and the conversion rate at 2,324/2,372 on Tuesday.
